title: 110_s3283
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow Congressional Gold Medal Act". Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow, born in 1913 on the Crow Indian Reservation, is the oldest living Crow Indian veteran. He is recognized for completing all 4 actions of counting coup during World War II, earning his first coup by leading a war party under fire. He earned his second and third coups by touching the first fallen enemy and knocking down a German soldier in France. Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow earned his fourth coup by stealing horses from an enemy camp during World War II. He was the first member of the Crow Tribe to earn a master's degree and has received 3 honorary PhDs. Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow has lectured worldwide on the effects of European culture contact. Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow, a noted tribal historian and anthropologist, has authored several books on Crow culture and was appointed tribal historian by the Crow Tribal Council in 1948. He is a renowned figure included in narratives of the West in major museums worldwide. Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow, a tribal historian and anthropologist, has received numerous awards for his contributions to Montana history and Western affairs. In 2008, he was honored with the French Legion of Honor Chevalier medal and the Bronze Star for his service in World War II. Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow, a highly accomplished role model, has been nominated for the Presidential Medal of Freedom for his valor and heroism in World War II, successful integration of his past, and education about his cultural heritage. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDAL.

The Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate will arrange for the presentation of a gold medal to Dr. Joseph Medicine Crow for his exceptional role as a Crow Tribe warrior, WWII Army Soldier, tribal historian, and author. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal.

SEC. 4. DUPLICATE MEDALS. The Secretary has the authority to create and sell duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal mentioned in section 3. The medals are considered national medals and numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will cover the production costs. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. Authorized charges against the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund will cover costs of medals struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited into the Fund.
